name: 西方書籍藝術：從中世紀到當代
description: This course provides an introduction to some of the key developments in illuminated manuscripts and printed books in the West, from the Middle Ages to the present. Through a series of in-depth case studies, the course will focus on medieval and Renaissance illuminated manuscripts from Western Europe, the transformation of book production with the development of printed books in Germany in the fifteenth century, and the various ways in which artists contributed to book production across Europe in the following centuries. Then, we will study the revival of handmade books in the nineteenth-century Arts and Crafts movement, and the emergence of new forms such as artists’ books and photobooks in the twentieth century. The study of some recent developments, such as the graphic novel and the impact of digital media, will bring the course to the present day. Consideration will be given to the changing relationships between images and texts, and how materials, techniques, and technologies have contributed to the changing nature of book arts over time.
goals: The aim of this course is: –to create an in-depth knowledge and understanding of key developments of book arts of the West from the Middle Ages to the present.
–to train students’ ability of analysis of form and iconography using the correct terminology.
–to improve students’ capacity for aesthetic judgment.
–to instruct students how to read and interpret sources of artistic theory.
–to promote students’ competencies to collect and interpret related literature and to encourage them to maintain a critical attitude toward scholarly opinions.
–give technical instructions for writing an academic text and composing a paper.

methodologies.note: In most classes the professor will deliver a presentation with a Powerpoint display, which will serves as a means to generate discussion in the class.
Students are free to ask questions, make comments, and lead discussions at any time in the classes, except when another student is delivering their presentation for assessment.
In session 16 there is a non-assessed teamwork quiz on the content of the course.
The class will visit libraries, book vendors, and private collections, as feasible.
Documentaries will be screened in classes, and digitized manuscripts and books studied online.
Most classes will contain case studies, introduced either by the professor or a student delivering their oral presentation for assessment.

grading.note: This mark is for attendance, punctuality, contribution to discussions and activities in class, and knowledge of the set texts.

Students develop the same topic delivered in the class presentation into a 6-8 page exhibition catalogue entry for a book, with footnotes, bibliography, and figures, taking into account the feedback for their oral presentation.
Students choose a topic from the course syllabus and deliver an approximately 45 minute oral presentation in class, supported with a Powerpoint or similar visual presentation.
